habitat_description:
In General:
During the winter, south of breeding areas, this species is almost exclusively maritime or coastal. Shores of salt water and less often freshwater lakes and rivers (Godfrey 1986). Occasional inland wanderer (quoted directly from Snell 2002).

Southwest:
Thayer’s gull breeds on rocky cliffs and ledges of vertical sea cliffs in the low and high Canadian Arctic Archipelago; most winter on the coast of the Pacific Northwest (Snell 2002). Winter inland occurrences are casual and are almost always juvenile or first year birds (Lawson 1973; Monson and Phillips 1981; Tove 1985; Andrews and Righter 1991; Snell 2002). It occurs in the SWReGAP region rarely and only during winter. Occurs locally in Utah, Colorado, and on the lower Colorado River but winter range is not fully understood (Ryser 2000; Snell 2002). Sightings in Utah are from urban areas and wetlands from Logan (Cache Co) south through the Wasatch Front to Provo (Behle et al. 1985; Tove 1985). It has been observed in Colorado primarily around the metropolitan area of Denver and near the foothills, but there are also records from Morgan, Weld, and Pueblo counties (Andrews and Righter 1991). Winter sightings in Arizona and Nevada are mostly from the lower Colorado River region (Lawson 1973; Monson and Phillips 1981; Alcorn 1988) but there are also a few records from inland lakes in Arizona (Lake Mary near Flagstaff and Bowie in Cochise Co.) as well as from the Reno area in Nevada (Ryser 1985). Thayer’s gull occurs rarely or accidentally in New Mexico  in San Juan Co. (Reeves 2000). Observations of this gull in Utah and Colorado seem to have increased since the 1970s (Tove 1985; Andrews and Righter 1991). Occurs in the SWReGAP region in winter on freshwater lakes and reservoirs and larger rivers (Snell 2002; Monson and Phillips 1981; Alcorn 1988; Tove 1985; Andrews and Righter 1991); also occurs in agricultural lands, metropolitan areas, lawns, and landfills (Snell 2002; Tove 1985; Behle et al. 1985; Andrews and Righter 1991; Lawson 1973). Including the agriculture landcover type resulted in a model that was too widespread. Although this species is known to use such areas on the Pacific coast (Snell 2002), in the SWReGAP region it has been reported only from garbage dumps and from wetlands. No hydrology buffer is included because the species occurs in upland areas, and because there was no specific distance from water restriction noted in the literature.  
Winter records from Colorado are from the valleys up to 1676 m in Colorado (Andrews and Righter 1991). This bird winters at sea level on the Pacific Coast (Snell 2002). Very little is known about Thayer’s gull, especially in terms of wintering ecology and migration movements; winter food may be limiting factor for this species because they do not occupy all suitable nesting sites in their breeding range (Snell 2002).
